pros: A truly inspiring and amazing cause, with some wonderful staff

review_title: Good cause, serious improvements needed at head office and Exec level.
pros:
Lack of process and red tape - great place to start your career because you have the freedom to get involved in what you want to but it can be frustrating when you are wanting to create long term change, see it as a stepping stone for your own career and then move on. 
The cause - spend as much time as you can in the centres, it’s where the good work happens and having that direct contact with visitors is unique for the sector.
cons:
Lack of change - if you want to create long term change this is not the place it will happen. Exec and CEO have been here too long and not welcome to change, even for the better of the charity. Change what you can in your role and then get out. 
Extremely inflexible working patterns - if you are someone who wants to be in the office 100%, great this is the role for you, if you want some flexibility you probably won’t get it here. CEO not open to working from home and as the only charity doing this they will lose people. 
Lack of progression - they will only promote people in Manager or Head Of positions after working for 10+ years which is oversight in charity sector. I suggest getting in at level you are happy doing for couple of years and then get out. Exec and CEO not interested in keeping people long term.

pros:
The need for Maggie's is stronger than ever. Its network of centres, staffed by dedicated professionals are meeting the needs of people living with cancer like no other charity.
Strong retention of programme and fundraising staff who have been in post 5-10years + who have built up meaningful relationships in local areas.
Ambitious charity who is growing, launching new capital projects annually, bringing with it opportunities to work for Maggie's across the UK.
Dedicated and supportive colleagues who collaborate on projects and plans
Varied job roles that challenge and aid development
cons: As a growing charity, resourcing of roles is on-going, and this can bring challenges when prioritising workload.

pros: Centres are amazing; they offer amazing support for Cancer

review_title: Great People, Great Cause, Awful Leadership
pros: You knew you were making a difference every day in the work that you did at Head Office, the team were absolutely lovely to work with and everyone was supportive and chipped in when needed.
cons: Leadership of the Directors and Board is constantly changing, with no realistic vision for the future. This has led to massively high staff turnover. There is also a lot of secrecy amongst the Directors and this has led to staff feeling like they aren't trusted. There is a brilliant atmosphere in all the Centres, but the atmosphere in the London Office is terrible. There is little to no career progression and management do not explore the skills and talents of their employees to look at possible promotions.

job_title: Centre Fundraising Manager in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
I have worked at Maggie’s for just under a year and in that time have been promoted from Centre Fundraiser to Fundraising Manager. This is a really exciting time for the charity, with continued growth leading to fresh investment in strategic central roles, doing great work supporting the day to day activities of the centre fundraising teams.
Colleagues are passionate, engaged, and supportive.
cons: While I love being based in the centre and seeing first-hand the results of my work, the busy environment can be a distraction when you need to focus.

pros: The centres themselves are amazing places staffed by wonderful passionate people who provide an incredible service.
cons: The executive leadership are not fit to lead. The CEO has found herself in a position for which she knows herself to be woefully unqualified and so wields her power like a despot, firing anyone who questions her and rewarding only sycophantic behaviour. The culture as a result is one of bullying, servility and obsequiousness. The workforce and the centres lack any semblance of diversity and the service as a result is one designed by rich people for rich people. Good people are hired and their opinions completely ignored.
